elements.text: We've talked enough, Doctor. Are we there?

Five past two in the morning. That was it, wasn't it? There'll be no airship left, not any more. She burned up in moments. Just blackened struts on a hillside, like the rib cage of a whale that's dropped from the sky.
Practical be blowed. I'll get by.
You'll have so much to explain.
Well, my French isn't too shabby. Uncle Jacques, remember?
Doors, tout de suite. I'm not going home, if that's what you're thinking.
So your Web of Time is safe. I'll find someone else to be, don't you worry.
I'll just sit and watch, pick grapes or something. Picking grapes won't change a thing.
I'll move around, from town to town, just watching, looking in.
Journey's end, as requested. Singapore harbour, New Year's Eve 1930. This is where you were headed, wasn't it, before you met me.
Ah, where better than that, just in case, you know, awkward encounters.
Oh, but I look like a tramp. And not the right sort of tramp for a place like this. What time is it?
Eleven fifty nine. Oh, hang on.
Bells ring, people cheer and shout Happy New Year. Then the firecrackers start.

The harbour's hardly changed since the East India Company set up shop. Steamers up from Jakarta bringing spices and teak. Junk boats defying the South China Seas. Smells of coffee and cuttlefish over the water.
I could live without the cuttlefish.
And firecrackers on New Years Eve making dragon's tails in the air.
Oh, it's perfect. Just perfect. Give me a hug. Mmm. Nice. I'm still leaving though.
If it won't make too much trouble with the Time Lords and all that.
I'll sort it out, don't you worry.
I'm going to close my eyes now and count to ten, and when I open them.
That's what I want. One. Two. Three. Four. Five. Six.
Happy New Year. I'm missing you too, Debs. No, no, no, can't be forgotten.
People on mobile phones, others ringing.
No, that skyline's not right. Too much glass and chrome.
Fireworks spelling out two oh oh eight.
Oh, come off it. You just couldn't do it, could you. Couldn't take the risk.
Oh, of leaving me in 1931. It's written all over your face.
I wasn't born yesterday, Doctor. You thought I wouldn't be able to resist it, didn't you. Going home to mummy and daddy, to Cissy and Peg, changing history.
No, that's not how it is at all.
Well, you're right. It'd have been hard. The hardest thing. And yes, I'd have been tempted every day for the rest of my life. Edith.
Charley, listen to me. Listen, listen. Something is wrong with the Tardis. Something has knocked her off course.
No, look, I can prove it. I can prove it. Just give me a minute, I'll prove it to you.
Just wait there. I'll be one minute in the Tardis.

One minute. One minute. Less now. Right. Earth, AD 2008, latitude one degree sixteen point nine minutes north, longitude one oh three degrees fifty point eight minutes east. Well, the galactic positioning system's fine. What now? Oh, think, think. Think!
Room two eleven, check. Mister Byron, check. Still no reply, sir.
Hello? (rings desk bell) Hello? Person here in need of assistance.
Oh, you spotted me. Do you have a pen?
Long thin thing you write with.
Anything else? A roll of parchment, perhaps?
That notepaper will do perfectly well.
We're here to help. Oh, Mister Byron, sir. I have him now.
Byron. Sure, no problem. Networks get jammed tighter than I don't know what on New Year's Eve.
You want to leave that for a guest?
Yeah, and my cousin's sheep farm just won Australia's title.
Er, well, it's for a man called the Doctor. He'll be here any minute.
You don't want to know Doctor who?
The Doctor has a permanent suite on floor six.
They say he's had it since 1872.
Five point three south. Don't tell me. Forty four point three east? You beauty!
Who shall I say it's from?
Charley. Charlotte Pollard. (walking away) Thank you!
One minute, mate. Excuse me, miss. What did that girl say her name was?
One minute. Well, two. Guess what I found? Charley? Charley!
Hey, miss, hey. Need a rickshaw? Where you going to, love?
Car horn, Charley gasps. Squeal of brakes.
More often it's those guys do the running over.
More in need of direction than directions. What did you call me?
I was in reception just now.
Oh. And I didn't notice you?
Oh, no. Don't be doing that to me.
You know, the whole intergalactic man of mystery thing.
Sorry. Memo to self, mysterious strangers not necessarily alien.
And you've found me, Byron Byron. So then, where am I going?
I've a fifty footer in the harbour.
Yacht. Best view of Singapore is from the water.
And you're sure you're not from outer space?
Darwin, Miss. They've even got electricity now. Well?
Sorry, do I look like I need convincing?
Your own pet taxi? How very very.
I think I've left something behind, that's all.
No, doesn't matter. Aren't you the gentleman.
Car door closes, The Doctor runs up and opens it.
I left a message for you.
I'm in import-export. You need a reference?
Message for Charley. Charley, I forgot. I found what sent the Tardis adrift.
It's like a swelling in space time, caused by pressure in the event ridges.
You should get that checked out, fella.
Oh, I'm going to. It's about three hundred miles out in the Karimata Straits, latitude nought degrees five point three minutes south, longitude one hundred and six degrees, forty three
And the epicentre, 000, sixty years back.
Oh. Hold on. Is that a gun in your pocket?
It was him with the rickshaw.
Oh, just find out what he wants.
Nice lady, I have to tell you that my name is Detective Sergeant Yu, from Jurong Division. You get out of the car.
So long as you're not planning on taking us down the station in that.
Two pound of plastic explosive under the chassis.
So sorry, Byron. You did not plant it there?
No, but you didn't stop the gang who did, right?
Smugglers blow up smugglers. Why should Yu care?
You be quiet. Yu just saved your life. You and your wife's.
Stand aside, please. Mister Byron is going for a drive now.
Detective Sergeant Yu, my name is Smith. Byron here is no smuggler.
We are running out of time.
And I think you'll find that Interpol are tracking my every move, even now. The fellow behind the hot chestnut stand, I last saw him in Mumbai. What was it Momma said?
And as for DCI Pollard here.
I knew the second I saw you in that bar in Casablanca. You coppers always smell the same. Handcuffs, please.
Get with the programme, Yu. She's been using Byron to get at me. But the worst of it is, she'll be wearing a wire.
Nice and tight. You don't want me getting away.
You say she is wearing a wire?
Of course. She'll have evidence that you stood by and let Byron burn, and he's her informer. How much time have we got?
I, not long. You, Byron, get out of the car.
The driver, too. Now, everybody back away slowly. What I'm going to do next is with my free hand, I'm going to raise this special sonic device, aim it at the bonnet of the car, then.
Right, I'm not hanging around. See ya later. (runs)
Hey, wait! Grr. Now what, Doctor?
In the absence of a cleverer idea, leg it!
No, no, you come back! I order you. You're all under arrest!
Doctor, I'm out of puff. That way.
Now, what did you do with the keys for these, Charley?
Oh, ha, ha, ha. Funny man. So, is there a story to these handcuffs?
Harry Houdini had them once. Well, at least that's what Crippen thought.
So then, intergalactic Miss of Mystery, what do you make of it all?
Well, temporal humps. Weird space time events centred around the fifteenth of January 1942, and a man who knows its precise latitude and longitude, and who was all prepared to kidnap you.
Oh no you don't. Don't you sucker me into joining you.
I've made my mind up, Doctor. It might, mightn't it?
One last lap of glory for the team?
In which case, latitude nought degrees five point three minutes south, longitude one hundred and six degrees forty three point three minutes east, here we come!
After all, what can possibly go wrong?
Telephone rings. An elderly lady counts the number of times.
[on phone]: And a Happy New year to you too.
Oh, another one. Byron, dear, I trust you're not being bothersome.
Well yes. More than four rings says you've something of vital importance to tell me, and don't let it be another dull death in the family.
[on phone]: You really are a prickly old cactus, aren't you.
At my age, dear, one can't spare the breath for pleasantries.
Well, don't then. And riddle me this. What's big and old and ugly, and sits slap bang in the Karimata Straits?
[on phone]: Well, there's a turn up.
There's a car on it's way. You might want to fix your face.
[on phone]: It's all too late for that.
I always wanted to say this. Are you ready to go back to Titanic?
She puts the phone down. He laughs.
The Tardis materialises and the door opens.
So it is. Hello? Big empty boat. Oh, nice piano. Bit dented.
I couldn't resist. Besides, there's no one here. Is it me, or is the tuning off?
It's off. There isn't, though. No one here these last sixty six years.
Mary Celeste. I suppose she was invaded by Daleks.
Second half of The Chase, part three. Charley yawns.
No, no, you carry on. Oh look, yeti footprints.
(sings) I made you look, made you stare, made you lose your underwear.
Skegness is so bracing. Come on then, out with the crackpot theory.

January 1942, Singapore is under siege. The Japanese are coming down through the Malay jungle, marching on the so-called impregnable fortress. Some even cycle. But the city is defenceless, ever since the Imperial Navy sunk the Repulse and the Prince of Wales.

And this would have been one of the very last ships out of Singapore harbour. Better to face the torpedoes and dive-bombers than the horrors of Changi Jail. She'd have been bursting at the seams with desperate men and women and children.
Not a pleasure cruise, then. Hang on. If she was bursting at the seams, the obvious question is
Ow. Ow, my fingers. There's acid on the handrail.
Oh, I don't know, but it stings like the devil.
Oh, Lord, you can see right through.
Yes, to the bone. Don't worry, it won't last. Blow on it.
You only got a touch. Should be stable now.
Just a fungal infection found in the vortex.
Well, I didn't bring it here.
Hang on. The boat's been in the vortex?
It's eating our footsteps, following our trail back.
Bit rusty in the joints, Doctor?
That's not funny. Temporal corrosion's a Tardis killer.
Charley, get off the dance floor.
Oh, howd you like that for a Black Bottom.
The boards are rotten, that's all.
It's not too bad over here.
Snap! Crash. The Doctor cries out.
Rope. It's a boat, there'll be rope.
[OC]: It'll be as rotten as the floor. Here, catch. You got it? There's spare cable under the console.
[OC]: No, take your time, why don't you.
[OC]: Quick, before it reaches the inner shell.
The what'll what? Right, cable, cable, cable. Ah. Oh. (shouts) Blue or pink?
Well, hang on, it's all snarled up.
Now what? Doctor, what's this mean? Hostile Action Displacement System engaged.
The Tardis doors close and it dematerialises.
After all, what can possibly go wrong? Stupid, stupid Doctor.
God in Heaven, what's to become of us?
Pull yourself together, that man. That kind of behaviour's downright Continental.
Share out your brandy, Borthwick. That'll keep him quiet.
All right, all right, gentlemen. Can't see in the dark, can I.
True, true. Colville, you all right, old man?
Oh, now I ain't drinking in a morgue. Fellas, heads up.
Oh, we're miles out now, and I've never seen such a miserable looking bunch of poms. Not outside Buckingham Palace, leastways.
Oh, stick it, Borthwick. We're far from home and we're far from dry, but we're on our way. Come on, smile. You too, young fella.
What do you suggest, a sing-song?
Then play, blast you, play. Johnny Nip ain't keeping me quiet. Right?

This is an old convict song, I believe, so Mister Byron might know it. It goes something like (sings) Farewell to old England forever. Farewell to my rum culls as well. Farewell to the well-known Old Bailey, where I used for to cut such a swell.
Singing toorali oorali ay. Singing toorali oorali addity, I'm bound for Botany Bay.
There's the Captain as is our commander, there's the bo'sun and all the ship's crew. There's the first and the second class passengers
Knows what we poor convicts go through.
Singing toorali oorali addity. Singing toorali oorali ay. Singing toorali oorali addity, and we're bound for Botany Bay.
Sorry to bother you. Is this 1942 by any chance?
Well now, seems we got a lady aboard.
Ah, there she is. There. Oh, would you believe it. Would you believe it back there?
I said, would you believe. Oh, never mind. The SS Batavia, back from the dead! Woo hoo!
Byron, dear. I said, Byron dear.
There's someone down there already, on the for'ard deck.
That's right, down here. Coo-ee! Don't mean to be stranded here for the rest of my natural life.
Charlotte Pollard, actually. Thank you. Are you sure we've not met before?
I know. Byron something, or something Byron.
Well now, if we have met, I didn't notice you. Damn.
Oh, don't you be doing that to me, again. Are there no other women on this ship?
Oh, it doesn't matter. Come here.
I'm cold, and I've got something to tell you.
There's a gun in my pocket.
So, Byron something or something Byron, it's time to start talking. Ow!
That's just your fingers, little lady. Course, I really do have a gun in my pocket.
Oh, you would. Hang on, what's that?
Oh, oldest trick in the book.
Oh, rabbits. Johnny (unintelligible, and probably just as well.)
A machine gun strafes the deck.
Hello, there. Thought I'd be stuck here for I don't know how long. You can't imagine how pleased I am to
Me too, Doctor. Over the moon, ain't we, fellas?
Curly. Don't tell me, these must be Larry and Mo.
Yes, and I've got my dignity.
Doctor, allow me to introduce my mother.
Hello, with my hands on my head.
I'm sorry. Boys, you know. They do get so over excited.
I noticed. And whom do I have the pleasure of addressing?
My name, Doctor, is Charlotte Pollard. Miss Pollard, to you.

DOCTOR: If that's what you want.
CHARLEY: That's what I want.
DOCTOR: In which case, latitude nought degrees five point three minutes south, longitude one hundred and six degrees forty three point three minutes east, here we come!
DOCTOR: After all, what can possibly go wrong?
CHARLEY: Plenty.
DOCTOR: O ye of little faith.
CHARLOTTE: One, two, three, four, and
CHARLOTTE: Good morning?
BYRON: [on phone]: And a Happy New year to you too.
CHARLOTTE: Oh, another one. Byron, dear, I trust you're not being bothersome.
BYRON: [on phone]: Bothersome? Me?
CHARLOTTE: Well yes. More than four rings says you've something of vital importance to tell me, and don't let it be another dull death in the family.
BYRON: [on phone]: You really are a prickly old cactus, aren't you.
CHARLOTTE: At my age, dear, one can't spare the breath for pleasantries.
BYRON: Well, don't then. And riddle me this. What's big and old and ugly, and sits slap bang in the Karimata Straits?
CHARLOTTE: [on phone]: Well, there's a turn up.
BYRON: There's a car on it's way. You might want to fix your face.
CHARLOTTE: [on phone]: It's all too late for that.
BYRON: Oh yeah, one other thing.
CHARLOTTE: [on phone]: Yes?
BYRON: I always wanted to say this. Are you ready to go back to Titanic?
CHARLOTTE: [on phone]: Hilarious.
CHARLEY: (gasps) A ballroom.
DOCTOR: A boat.
CHARLEY: So it is. Hello? Big empty boat. Oh, nice piano. Bit dented.
DOCTOR: Charley.
CHARLEY: I couldn't resist. Besides, there's no one here. Is it me, or is the tuning off?
DOCTOR: It's off. There isn't, though. No one here these last sixty six years.
CHARLEY: You mean we're not in 1942?
DOCTOR: The Tardis didn't fancy it.
CHARLEY: Ah. Your temporal hump.
DOCTOR: I expect so. SS Batavia.
CHARLEY: How did you know that?
DOCTOR: Lifebelt.
CHARLEY: Not the Marie Celeste, then.
DOCTOR: Mary Celeste.
CHARLEY: Mary Celeste. I suppose she was invaded by Daleks.
DOCTOR: As a matter of fact
DOCTOR: Am I boring you?
CHARLEY: No, no, you carry on. Oh look, yeti footprints.
DOCTOR: Eh?
CHARLEY: (sings) I made you look, made you stare, made you lose your underwear.
DOCTOR: Through here.
CHARLEY: Skegness is so bracing. Come on then, out with the crackpot theory.
DOCTOR: January 1942, Singapore is under siege. The Japanese are coming down through the Malay jungle, marching on the so-called impregnable fortress. Some even cycle. But the city is defenceless, ever since the Imperial Navy sunk the Repulse and the Prince of Wales.
CHARLEY: And?
DOCTOR: And this would have been one of the very last ships out of Singapore harbour. Better to face the torpedoes and dive-bombers than the horrors of Changi Jail. She'd have been bursting at the seams with desperate men and women and children.
CHARLEY: Not a pleasure cruise, then. Hang on. If she was bursting at the seams, the obvious question is
DOCTOR: Yes. Where indeed.
CHARLEY: Ah!
DOCTOR: Something wrong?
CHARLEY: Ow. Ow, my fingers. There's acid on the handrail.
DOCTOR: Acid?
CHARLEY: Oh, I don't know, but it stings like the devil.
DOCTOR: Let me see. Nasty.
CHARLEY: Oh, Lord, you can see right through.
DOCTOR: Yes, to the bone. Don't worry, it won't last. Blow on it.
CHARLEY: What?
DOCTOR: Go on. Better?
CHARLEY: A bit.
DOCTOR: You only got a touch. Should be stable now.
CHARLEY: Yes, but what is it?
DOCTOR: Corrosion.
CHARLEY: What, rust?
DOCTOR: Temporal corrosion.
CHARLEY: Oh, here we go.
DOCTOR: Just a fungal infection found in the vortex.
CHARLEY: Well, I didn't bring it here.
DOCTOR: No.
CHARLEY: Hang on. The boat's been in the vortex?
DOCTOR: It'd explain. Oh, no.
CHARLEY: It's spreading.
DOCTOR: It's eating our footsteps, following our trail back.
CHARLEY: Back where?
BOTH: The Tardis!
CHARLEY: Bit rusty in the joints, Doctor?
DOCTOR: That's not funny. Temporal corrosion's a Tardis killer.
CHARLEY: Then get those legs oh!
DOCTOR: Charley, get off the dance floor.
CHARLEY: Oh, howd you like that for a Black Bottom.
DOCTOR: Come on!
CHARLEY: But the floor's all corroded.
DOCTOR: Rot.
CHARLEY: No, I can see it.
DOCTOR: The boards are rotten, that's all.
CHARLEY: You're sure?
DOCTOR: It's not too bad over here.
CHARLEY: You're sure?
DOCTOR: I'll prove it.
DOCTOR: See?
DOCTOR: Oh, wait. That doesn't sound
CHARLEY: Doctor? Doctor?
DOCTOR: [OC]: Down here.
CHARLEY: Are you all right?
DOCTOR: [OC]: Do I look all right?
CHARLEY: Rope. It's a boat, there'll be rope.
DOCTOR: [OC]: It'll be as rotten as the floor. Here, catch. You got it? There's spare cable under the console.
CHARLEY: What, in the Tardis?
DOCTOR: [OC]: Where'd you think?
CHARLEY: Well, I'd best hurry.
DOCTOR: [OC]: No, take your time, why don't you.
DOCTOR: [OC]: How's she looking?
CHARLEY: Paintworks bubbling, kind of.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Quick, before it reaches the inner shell.
CHARLEY: Well, what happens then?
CHARLEY: The HADS'I kick in, probably.
CHARLEY: The what'll what? Right, cable, cable, cable. Ah. Oh. (shouts) Blue or pink?
DOCTOR: [OC]: Doesn't matter.
CHARLEY: Well, hang on, it's all snarled up.
CHARLEY: Now what? Doctor, what's this mean? Hostile Action Displacement System engaged.
DOCTOR: [OC]: Oh, no!
CHARLEY: The doors!
DOCTOR: After all, what can possibly go wrong? Stupid, stupid Doctor.
MAN: God in Heaven, what's to become of us?
BORTHWICK: Pull yourself together, that man. That kind of behaviour's downright Continental.
COLVILLE: Share out your brandy, Borthwick. That'll keep him quiet.
BORTHWICK: I suppose.
BORTHWICK: Damn.
BORTHWICK: All right, all right, gentlemen. Can't see in the dark, can I.
COLVILLE: Means the Japs can't, either.
BORTHWICK: True, true. Colville, you all right, old man?
BRYON: Oh, now I ain't drinking in a morgue. Fellas, heads up.
COLVILLE: But, the noise? The Japs?
BYRON: Oh, we're miles out now, and I've never seen such a miserable looking bunch of poms. Not outside Buckingham Palace, leastways.
BORTHWICK: Mister Byron.
BYRON: Oh, stick it, Borthwick. We're far from home and we're far from dry, but we're on our way. Come on, smile. You too, young fella.
COLVILLE: What do you suggest, a sing-song?
BYRON: Why, do you play?
COLVILLE: A little.
BYRON: Then play, blast you, play. Johnny Nip ain't keeping me quiet. Right?
COLVILLE: This is an old convict song, I believe, so Mister Byron might know it. It goes something like (sings) Farewell to old England forever. Farewell to my rum culls as well. Farewell to the well-known Old Bailey, where I used for to cut such a swell.
ALL: Singing toorali oorali addity
BYRON: Oh, come on, chaps!
ALL: Singing toorali oorali ay. Singing toorali oorali addity, I'm bound for Botany Bay.
COLVILLE: There's the Captain as is our commander, there's the bo'sun and all the ship's crew. There's the first and the second class passengers
BYRON: That's you, mate. (laughter)
COLVILLE: Knows what we poor convicts go through.
ALL: Singing toorali oorali addity. Singing toorali oorali ay. Singing toorali oorali addity, and we're bound for Botany Bay.
CHARLEY: Sorry to bother you. Is this 1942 by any chance?
BYRON: Well now, seems we got a lady aboard.
CHARLEY: You.
BYRON: Ah, there she is. There. Oh, would you believe it. Would you believe it back there?
CHARLOTTE: Pardon?
BYRON: I said, would you believe. Oh, never mind. The SS Batavia, back from the dead! Woo hoo!
CHARLOTTE: Well, quite.
BYRON: Pilot, take her down.
CHARLOTTE: Byron, dear. I said, Byron dear.
BYRON: Yeah?
CHARLOTTE: There's someone down there already, on the for'ard deck.
BYRON: What? Oh, rabbits. Him.
DOCTOR: That's right, down here. Coo-ee! Don't mean to be stranded here for the rest of my natural life.
BYRON: After you, little Miss Stowaway.
CHARLEY: Charlotte Pollard, actually. Thank you. Are you sure we've not met before?
BYRON: Reckon I'd remember. I'm
CHARLEY: I know. Byron something, or something Byron.
BYRON: Well now, if we have met, I didn't notice you. Damn.
CHARLEY: Oh, don't you be doing that to me, again. Are there no other women on this ship?
BYRON: Nope.
CHARLEY: But the Doctor says
BYRON: Who?
CHARLEY: Oh, it doesn't matter. Come here.
BYRON: Where? Oh, cosy.
CHARLEY: I'm cold, and I've got something to tell you.
BYRON: What's that, then.
CHARLEY: There's a gun in my pocket.
BYRON: Whoa there.
CHARLEY: So, Byron something or something Byron, it's time to start talking. Ow!
BYRON: That's just your fingers, little lady. Course, I really do have a gun in my pocket.
CHARLEY: Oh, you would. Hang on, what's that?
BYRON: Oh, oldest trick in the book.
CHARLEY: No, that!
BYRON: Oh, rabbits. Johnny (unintelligible, and probably just as well.)
CHARLEY: Johnny who?
BYRON: Down!
DOCTOR: Hello, there. Thought I'd be stuck here for I don't know how long. You can't imagine how pleased I am to
BYRON: Me too, Doctor. Over the moon, ain't we, fellas?
DOCTOR: Fellas?
BYRON: My choice swagmen. Curly?
CURLY: He's covered.
DOCTOR: Curly. Don't tell me, these must be Larry and Mo.
CURLY: Hands on your head.
DOCTOR: Whatever you say.
CHARLOTTE: Oh, must I?
BYRON: It's all right. I've gotcha.
CHARLOTTE: Yes, and I've got my dignity.
BYRON: Doctor, allow me to introduce my mother.
DOCTOR: Hello.
BYRON: Hands on your head!
DOCTOR: Hello, with my hands on my head.
CHARLOTTE: I'm sorry. Boys, you know. They do get so over excited.
DOCTOR: I noticed. And whom do I have the pleasure of addressing?
CHARLOTTE: My name, Doctor, is Charlotte Pollard. Miss Pollard, to you.

elements.text: Same height, I suppose. Same eyes, same chin, once.
Byron, dear, where did you say you encountered this creature?
How old are you? If it's not a personal question.
How old are you! How old are you?
Nine hundred and, oh, we're talking Earth years, aren't we?
Breathtaking. I'm in my eighty fifth year. I've no idea why I'm telling you that.
Oh, well that's all right. My Charlotte Pollard was born on the day the Titanic sank. She'd be ninety six now.
She does? Oh, she does, except. Eighteen and a half when I met her. three or four years messing around with me, twenty one?
Is he wittering at us or despite us?
He's playing us for fools, and we ain't got the time. Curly, your guys need to start shifting the gear.
Time. Yes, if she, if she went back in time. Miss Pollard, when exactly was your twenty first? Please, indulge me.
Lost without trace, except for a single survivor.
Picked up from a lonely lifeboat, cold, wet and amnesiac. Me.
Twenty one then, eighty five now. Charley?
She's away, back to Batan or wherever.
Once you've got off me I will be. Oh, there's a gun in your pocket and it's sticking right in my ribs.
Oh, that was a close one.
Oh, she was just taking a shot at us for the hell of it.
Ah, she was a spotter. She'll be radioing our position now. There'll be a sub on the way.
Oh, that's not good, is it.
Hey there, seaman. Simons, isn't it?
Less of the Sir stuff, eh?
Captain wants you, sir. Mister Byron, I mean. Said it was dead urgent. Your operator's dead. Who's this?
You want to watch this one, Charley. He's got the eye, but I've got the hands.
Byron gooses Charley, by the sound of it, and laughs.
Well, I could ask the same of you.
Sir, should there be passengers on the bridge? She is a passenger, isn't she?
Quiet, mate. I'm enjoying the view.
What don't you remember, Miss Pollard?
I was a passenger on the Batavia. When they picked me up, all I had was my name and a bad case of the Post Traumatics, as I believe they call it now.
The Byron family looked after me. They hoped that one day I'd remember, but alas.
And you don't remember me at all?
I've never met you before in my life.
Okay, okay. Stand well back, everyone.
Byron, I do hope we're not going to be left stranded.
'Copter's not safe on a rust farm like this. Be back in a couple of hours. 'Sides, there's always the Doctor's boat. Isn't that right?
You got yourself here somehow, you and your girlfriend. Now, where is she, by the way?
You're wearing my patience, mate. Your girlfriend's alias proved it. You know everything there is to know about this ship. Curly? Check his pockets.
You don't want to go looking in there.
Trust me, mate, it's too cold a morning for a strip-search. Anything?
You had a pair of cuffs in there last night.
Don't you have mice in Australia?
Sure, but we don't keep mousetraps primed in our pockets.
(laughs) Priceless! Do you know, Doctor, I'm warming to you.
I told you not to go looking in there.
No, but I think a person's private pockets are private, and if you will plunder a person's private pockets
And you know all about plunder, pal.
I'm sorry, I don't follow you.
The Batavia's not yours to pillage. My granddad chartered her out of Singapore. My granddad owned everything aboard. She's mine in law, and I won't have some ponced up pirate pip me to the post.
Well, you can't call it salvage.
Doctor, you know perfectly well this ship didn't carry refugees. The women and children, those that could, they left on the official boats.
But a certain breed of rich colonials fellas, they was jiggered if they was being left behind in Singapore.
Jiggered if they were leaving their antiques, their artworks, their cars, even their gold to the invading enemy.
That's right. Gold. Curly, quit your whimpering and get your guys together. We're going to crack open the hold of this tub, and we're going to go home rich.
Dead slow, helmsman. Oi, mind how you go, mister.
Owner on the bridge, Captain, sir.
All right, boy, you're in the Merchant Marine, not the Navy.
Who's this, if you don't mind.
I won't have women on my bridge. Won't have stowaways, neither.
This is Miss Pollard. My boat, my rules.
Thank you, Cap'n Bligh. We're here to see about your operator, is that right?
Aye, he's here. Took one of them bullets right between the eyes. Messy, ain't it.
Mate, that's horrible. Poor old Jim.
We need to get your gizmo working.
What do you mean, can't? I only ran this trip because you promised we'd be safe.
You ran this trip for Aussie Pounds, and plenty of them.
What is this gizmo, anyhow? The big globe whatsit?
Don't look at me, I don't understand it.
Jin here defected from the Japs with blueprints to this gizmo. Reckoned it could guarantee the Batavia's safe passage. No chances of getting sunk.
Oh, so it's a sort of radar jamming system.
Well, that much is fairly obvious. This big globe whatsit spins around and whips up some sort of dense magnetic field, and. I'm sorry, am I getting too technical?
No, no, no. No, you go on.
I mean, I'm no expert, but this stuff rubs off on you. I saw something similar once on Quaxon Four.
Oh, yes. And the cabling here helps bounce the field all over.
Old Jin called it an EM pulse. Reckoned it'd bend light around the boat, make it, you
know, invisible. The Yanks are working on something like it in Philadelphia, he said.
Only now he's dead, and he was the only man
Knew how to work it, yeah.
But it'd be working now if you powered it up.
So what do we do about it, Miss?
How far away is that storm?
Hmm. Good. I've just had a flash of inspiration.
Byron roars and hits the bulkhead.
Byron, dear, you'll do yourself a damage.
How do you open these compartments?
It'll take more than a kick. There's six inches of reinforced metal here, and the mechanism's rusted shut.
I will not be denied. Curly!
Fetch the you know what from up top. Both cases.
And what, pray, is the you know what?
You'd best be getting yourself up top too.
The what, I assume, is the plastic explosive on deck. The real question is, how does he hope to blow a set of six inch thick reinforced door wide open without sinking the ship?
Yeah, well, maybe I could bring her to port, if I didn't know I had a rival organisation on my
Rival organisation? Byron, there's just me and Miss Pollard.
The other Miss Pollard. Byron, I've no interest in booty. It's the mystery of this boat that bothers me.
The only mystery is what was so valuable my granddad had to shut it up behind so much steel!

What's this ship been doing these last sixty six years? Why has she only shown up now? What happened here on the night of the fifteenth of January 1942? And most important of all, what happened to you, Miss Pollard?
I don't doubt it. You're eighty five. What are you going to do with the gold in the hold? I want to solve the mystery of you. I don't see your son making much progress on that score, do you?
I don't know why I don't just chuck you overboard. And you, mother.
Byron dear, how would you ever have found the Batavia if it hadn't been for me?
Doctor, would you be so kind as to take this wrench and administer to my son the whack on the head he deserves.
(laughs) I'd like to see him try.
Oh, the decline of English manhood.
Spare the rod, spoil the child. Come on, Doctor.
He's out cold. You can't just leave him.
Well, the three stooges will be back any minute. Doctor, I'm here to solve the mystery of me, as you put it, and I'm beginning to think you represent my very best chance of doing so.
Now, where do you suggest we start?
Ah, well, er, there's a mast I can't work out. An aerial above the bridge?
Move it, you sows. Up! Up! Up!
The aerial needs to be higher still.
Much higher, and it's my men you'll be using as lightning conductors.
Oh, this is hopeless. Put a bit of effort on, or do I have to shin up there and show you how it's done!
This stuff ain't going to blow without the detonators, Curly.
It ain't gonna blow at all if you get it wet, stupid. Hey boss, you want us to start unpacking? Boss? He's out of it. Don't think he's breathing, even.
You're not going to give him mouth to mouth.
Curly starts resuscitation and Byron splutters.
What are you trying to do, kiss me? Oh, help me up.
What happened? Didn't think that Doctor guy would have it in him.
It wasn't him, it was. Where's Miss Pollard?
That creep must have taken her hostage.
You guys drop that stuff. We're pairing off. I'll go with Mister Byron. That Doctor is going to wish he was never born. Come on.
Squeaking wheel turning to open a stuck hatch.
There! All it takes is a little backbone.
It's not my backbone I'm worried about, it's my shoulder.
Turn the light on, will you?
You knew where the switch was, without looking.
Miss Pollard, you've been on the bridge before. What else is submerged in your subconscious? Oh. Now what's this?

A pulse generator. The Americans were working on something similar round about 1942, trying to bend light around an object, making it invisible across all possible spectra. I saw something similar once on Quaxon Four. Trouble is, it hardly ever worked.
Only this one does. Residual energy traces, just a few hours old. Tell me, was there a storm out here last night?
I like to listen to Wagner of an evening, not the shipping report.
Shame. I've got a theory, you see.

Someone's erected a mast outside to power this thing up. The Batavia's been drifting for sixty six years, but she's hardly ever spotted because every time a storm kicks up the device gets powered up and she just disappears.
Except there'd need to have been a near constant storm for that to work.
Why not see if it's blown a gasket, or whatever.
No, not like that. Engage the port flange first.
Oops. I rather think I did it again.
I rather think you did. Charlotte Pollard, why was it you were fiddling about with this machine in 1942?
Strip off. Simons'll find you some dry things.
Belay that, Simons. You'll be lucky.
So, when is this machine gonna be working?
Soon as we get a lightning strike.
Johnny'll see us any minute, and when he does, fsh! Boom.
And the telegraph gives us what, storm warnings?
The telegraph, Miss Pollard, is wired to the innards of this big globe whatsit, which gives us a log of its functions.
It's mathematics. Look, refractive index here tells me. Ew.
Unless. Unless the vectors are calculated in
Don't move. You so much as twitch and I'll fill you with lead.
Oh, Byron. Ouch. What you need is some vinegar and brown paper.
And what you need, Mother, is a great
Oh, please. It's like the Australasian branch of the Borgias.
You should come to our family Christmas.
Fascinating. Would anyone like to know something important about this ship?
Oh, sorry. It's the other guys.
Curly. Come in. That you, Barnes? I can't raise them. (static)
[OC]: I'm warning you. Get back or I'll
Barnes? This is Byron. Barnes, talk to me.
More weapons, more screams, then silence.
I think Mister Barnes has reached the limit of his conversation.
Doctor, if this is anything to do with you
Your associates are under fire. I suggest we go and look for them.
Oh, just come on, will you?
The globe whatsit powers up. ASDIC is still pinging out its contact.
Your mast is lit up like a Christmas tree in a fireworks factory.
The Japs'll be able to see us for miles around.
Well, not for long, I hope. Byron, you're bringing the wet in.
Captain, would you consider putting bromide in the grog?
Ah, is it supposed to be smoking like that?
It's our only chance. Leave it be.
Turn it off before it explodes!
Well, if you won't, I will.
Electricity arcs. The Captain screams. Thud.
Ah, stop it. Somebody stop it!
Sure you did. Trouble is, the Captain's fried, and the boat, she's still a sitting duck.
They're dead, Byron. Riddled with bullets.
Oh, Doctor, are we not at home to Mister Tact?
Because they were my mates, and it was your men killed them.
Easy, Curly, easy. We ain't killing him.
Not here. We're killing him up top. Jiggered if I'm dragging his corpse all that way just to chuck it overboard.
Silly stupid idiots. Come on, basic observation. The walls.
Of course, bullet impacts. Here, here, here.
Ricochets. It was their own bullets killed them, firing wildly in a closed area like this.
Don't you teach your guys anything, Curly?
What was it made them open fire in the first place?
It's getting closer. Okay, I'm going to call for assistance.
Won't that give away our position?
Way things are, we're going to be sending out a Mayday soon enough. We call out a few minutes early, could mean a few more lives get saved.
No, but I'm doing it anyway. (radio) Mayday. Mayday. This is Steamship Batavia, about three hundred miles out in the Karimata Strait. Latitude nought degrees five point three minutes south.
Longitude er, one oh six degrees
Forty three point three minutes east.
Forty three point three minutes east. Urgent assistance required. Repeat. Urgent assistance required. We are under attack. We are
I reckon I can hear something. Yeah? Yeah, gotcha. Now speak up. Oh, speak up, damn it.
[OC]: Your message has been received. Prepare to receive transmission.
Are we saved? Is that what it means?
Your men were firing down towards the bulkhead to the hold.
There's nothing there. No entrances, no exits, just a six inch thick immovable bulkhead.
Yeah, could you spare us this ghost ship stuff.
Okay, that does it. Curly, take my mother and lock her in the brig.
It's for your own safety, Mother dear, just in case the Doctor does have men aboard.
Gonna need another pair of hands to help me set the charges and transport the loot up top.
I think she must have dropped you on the head as a baby.
Like she was ever around long enough. Come on, get the case open. The gold in the hold is gonna be mine.
Something to the innards of the pulse generator. But he knows nothing about the machine. Nothing. He's being instructed.
Oh, give the girl a coconut.
Girl? Oh. How did you know?

Hmm. Let me guess. Life with mater and pater was such a drag, and one day you thought blow this, I'm off on an adventure. Next thing you're dragged up on a fantastic craft headed halfway across the world and thinking, how do I get out of this? It takes one to know one, all right.
You mean, you're really a boy?

Well, it wasn't quite like that. They sent me away to a finishing school. I got out onto this trawler. They found me, hauled me up before the purser. I couldn't understand what they were saying. They handed me these papers, made me sign. I didn't realise it was a contract.
And I thought I was rubbish.
Pleased to meet you. Oh, hand on, that noise has stopped.
Byron, what have you done in there?
There are amendments to the refractive index. The port flange recalibrated. There is no cause for alarm.
A hostile submarine vessel. It is of no concern.
Are you mad? We're dead in the water!
Too late. The sub'll have us sighted. We've got to warn the passengers. Charley, come on.
Guess what, Doctor? We haven't sunk the ship.
Really. Aren't you worried I'll run off with the gold in the hold?
No. But if there is someone in there, I could use a human shield. Shift it!
Madeleine, you're going to start a panic.
Oh? And who made you the world authority? Who are you, anyway?
Oh, the HADS again. Hostile Action something something. It means it. It means she's predicted a fatal event. Something inevitable.
It's too late. We're done for.
(sotto) Doctor? Doctor, can you see anything? Is it gold?
Yes! Come on, help me get them open.
There's better stuff past the next bulkhead. I read the manifest. There must be!
(sotto) Something five foot four with a wrinkled hide and a vicious tongue.
He's in the brig. Well, if one will underestimate old ladies.
Correction. They're coming from all around.
Just stick with me, Miss Pollard. Try not to panic.
But I remember. I remember what they are.
Cybermen. They're called Cybermen, aren't they.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
DOCTOR: No, you're not. Can't be.
CHARLOTTE: I beg your pardon?
DOCTOR: Same height, I suppose. Same eyes, same chin, once.
CHARLOTTE: Byron, dear, where did you say you encountered this creature?
DOCTOR: How old are you? If it's not a personal question.
BYRON: Oh ho! Nice one, mate.
CHARLOTTE: How old are you! How old are you?
DOCTOR: Nine hundred and, oh, we're talking Earth years, aren't we?
CHARLOTTE: Breathtaking. I'm in my eighty fifth year. I've no idea why I'm telling you that.
DOCTOR: Oh, well that's all right. My Charlotte Pollard was born on the day the Titanic sank. She'd be ninety six now.
BYRON: She looks good on it.
DOCTOR: She does? Oh, she does, except. Eighteen and a half when I met her. three or four years messing around with me, twenty one?
CHARLOTTE: Is he wittering at us or despite us?
BYRON: He's playing us for fools, and we ain't got the time. Curly, your guys need to start shifting the gear.
CURLY: On it.
DOCTOR: Time. Yes, if she, if she went back in time. Miss Pollard, when exactly was your twenty first? Please, indulge me.
CHARLOTTE: 1942.
DOCTOR: 1942, the year this ship sailed.
CHARLOTTE: The year this ship vanished.
BYRON: Lost without trace, except for a single survivor.
CHARLOTTE: Picked up from a lonely lifeboat, cold, wet and amnesiac. Me.
DOCTOR: Twenty one then, eighty five now. Charley?
BYRON: She's away, back to Batan or wherever.

DOCTOR: Right, we're all set up here. Pulse generator is in perfect phase with the Tardis's guidance systems. She'll kick-start the device soon as I dematerialise.
CHARLOTTE: Well, do it, then.
DOCTOR: All I've got to do is find the right place to translate us to.
CHARLOTTE: Timbuktu, Shangri-La, the Hanging Gardens of Babylon.
DOCTOR: There, got it. Spitzbergen.
CHARLOTTE: What's a Spitzbergen?
DOCTOR: Well, what's seventy five miles north northeast of Spitzbergen at this precise moment in space time, in fact.
CHARLOTTE: Amaze me.
DOCTOR: I will.
CYBERMAN: Pulse generator activated. We are being translated.
DOCTOR: All right, then. I'll show you, but you'll have to be quick.
CHARLOTTE: Oh, no.
CYBERMAN: Destroy them. Destroy them at once.
DOCTOR: Too late, pal. You've been translated.
CHARLOTTE: For heavens sake, it's right in front of you. Iceberg!
DOCTOR: You see, what's seventy five miles north northeast of Spitzbergen is the biggest iceberg in open water since the Titanic went down.
CYBERMAN: You will steer this vessel clear.
DOCTOR: Too late. Brace yourselves.
CYBERMAN: What is happening?
CYBERMAN: 2: The hull is breached.
CYBERMAN: Emergency. Emergency. All Cybermen to repair hull breach.
CYBERMAN: 3: Confirm
CYBERMAN: Seal the hold. Imperative. Seal the hold.
CHARLOTTE: I don't believe you just did that.
DOCTOR: I don't quite believe it myself.
CHARLOTTE: It's just, Byron.
DOCTOR: I know. I'm so sorry.
CHARLOTTE: What's wrong with me? I can't even cry for him.
DOCTOR: You will. But first there's somewhere we have to go.
CHARLOTTE: Go?
DOCTOR: Singapore harbour, 1931, and then, if you like, we'll go on. There's so many more places to see, Charley. I'm just sorry we missed out on those sixty six years. Oh, Charley, it's such a big universe, and now I get to show it to you all over again.
CHARLOTTE: No.
DOCTOR: Oh. Well, if you're sure.
CHARLOTTE: No, I mean I've remembered something. Curly.
DOCTOR: Who?
CHARLOTTE: Curly, the chap I locked up in the brig.
DOCTOR: You can't imagine he's
CHARLOTTE: Doctor, we can't just leave him to drown.
DOCTOR: Oh, this is madness.
DOCTOR: Utter madness.
CHARLOTTE: The brig is just round the corner. We can make it.
DOCTOR: I can make it. You're going nowhere. Right.
CHARLOTTE: Deep breath now
DOCTOR: I'm not a mermaid.
CHARLOTTE: No.
CHARLOTTE: You're something altogether more fantastic.
CHARLOTTE: Doctor? Doctor, is that you?
CHARLOTTE: CYBER-BYRON: You. I know you. Mother.
CHARLOTTE: No. Byron, please. Byron.
MADELEINE: This is no good. We're all just waiting to die.
BORTHWICK: What do you propose we do about it?
MADELEINE: Here. Cyberman, here.
CYBERMAN: You will continue to await conversion.
MADELEINE: But you've got to see this. That corrosion of yours. Look, it's in the piano.
CYBERMAN: Corrosion not present. Why do you lie?
MADELEINE: Now, Borthwick, the lid!
BORTHWICK: Had enough, do you think?
MADELEINE: No, again.
DOCTOR: Charley? Charley, the door was open. He wasn't there. He's got a chance. Charley?
CHARLOTTE: They say your whole life rushes before you. They're right.
DOCTOR: You're wounded. We'll get you to the Tardis Sickbay.
CHARLOTTE: It was Byron, Doctor. I didn't see where he went.
DOCTOR: Hush, now. I'm trying to work out that fireman's lift.
CHARLOTTE: My whole life, before my eyes. The first twenty one included.
DOCTOR: Ah, but wasn't that the best? You and me (effort) with Orson Welles, remember?
CHARLOTTE: No. No, my name is not Charlotte Pollard.
DOCTOR: Charley, Charley, you must hold on. Remember.
CHARLOTTE: My name is Madeleine. Madeleine Fairweather. I was with her all those many years ago. Charley, Charlotte Pollard, on this boat all those many years ago. I'm so sorry.
DOCTOR: What happened to Charley? Please.
CHARLOTTE: So sorry.
DOCTOR: No, no, no, no, don't die. You have to tell me. Tell me what happened. Please. Please, please.
BORTHWICK: Is it dead?
MADELEINE: I should think so. All of you, listen to me. We're going to make our way out to the lifeboats. Find anything you can to use as a weapon. Table leg, a fire axe, a piano wire would make a garrotte. Anything.
CYBERMAN: Resistance is futile.
BORTHWICK: Here they come.
YOUNG MAN: Up and at them, chaps.
BORTHWICK: Damn.
CYBERMAN: Leader, this rebellion is quashed. Awaiting instructions.
MADELEINE: Leader?
MADELEINE: CYBER-CHARLEY: I am their leader. You will all be converted.
MADELEINE: Charley!
MADELEINE: CYBER-CHARLEY: You will become like me.

elements.text: Charley, what have they done to you?
CYBER-CHARLEY: I am improved. My mind is clear. Soon my body will be augmented.
Charley, you have to fight it!
CYBER-CHARLEY: My Cybermen are fitting conversion apparatus below deck. You will not have long to wait.
CYBER-CHARLEY: That would be wasteful. Cyberman, restrain her.
CYBER-CHARLEY: You will watch my conversion. You will see your fear is unreasonable. Then you will follow.
Oh God, somebody save us. Won't somebody save us, please? CYBER-CHARLEY: Cyber conversion is your salvation. It will be extended to all of your kind. Here in your future, then in your past.
Spontaneous electrical discharge from mast caused (voice dies)
That's Saint Elmo's Fire, Cyber-lady. It's a sign!
Update. Pulse generator reactivated. Translation beginning. CYBER-CHARLEY: Impossible. Shut it down.
It's happening again. We're being translated!
Whooshes and was that a touch of Tardis?
CYBER-CHARLEY: Update, local dateline, one nine four two microunit one fifteen.
You can open your eyes now, Borthwick. We're home.
Everyone listen. We've made it back home.
It is irrelevant. Conversions will continue.
We're home and we're alive. It means there's hope.
Hope is a corruption of probably outcome.
Devil, angel, depends on your perspective. I am the Doctor.
You're barking up the wrong tree there.
Quiet. How do you know my name?
Later. Now, Charley, I reckon it's about time we gave these Cybermen something to think about. I'm thinking escape strategy seven.
CYBER-CHARLEY: Escape strategy will not succeed.
Oh, come on. The old diversion and counter-diversion, it's a classic. Never fails. CYBER-CHARLEY: Cybermen.
Leader? Oh, Charley, that's brilliant. How did you pull that off?
CYBER-CHARLEY: This man is an enemy of the Cyber race. Cybermen, disable him.
Ah. In which case, back off.
Funny, I always took this nasty little signature to read A Hitler.
Everyone file past me, nice and orderly. I'll ward them off.
Charley, I don't know what it is they've done to you, but you are coming too. CYBER-CHARLEY: No. The weakness of the Cyber race does not apply to me.
CYBER-CHARLEY: This gold will be disposed of. Cybermen, advance.
Wait. Wait, wait, wait, wait, wait. Don't you want to know how I managed to translate the Batavia back?

Well, having been clever enough to tow the future Batavia by Tardis to another space time location, I scanned this latitude and longitude for the characteristic signature of an EM pulse, and what do you know? I found one, in the year 500,002.
Is he quite right in the head, this chap?
All I had to do then was broadcast a reactivation protocol into the future, and, well, here we all are.
CYBER-CHARLEY: Update. Cause of spontaneous translation recorded. Cybermen, continue with conversions.
You will move to the hold.
Wait, wait. What I didn't tell you is I had to make one small but crucial modification to the translation vectors. The time is ten past two, and thirty seconds.
So I shifted the translation vectors to about half a mile off to avoid the ship being struck by a pair of Japanese torpedoes.
CYBER-CHARLEY: This is another escape strategy. Keep them talking. It will not succeed.
Meaning those torpedoes are what, fifty yards off the starboard bow?
They cruised straight past her original location, but here they are again. Thought I
might need a distraction. Brace yourselves!
CYBER-CHARLEY: Confirm. Torpedoes to starboard. Initiate evasive action.
Escape strategy three with a dash of four. Hold on tight!
CYBER-CHARLEY: Alert. Hull is breached in two place.
She'll be taking on water fast.
CYBER-CHARLEY: All Cybermen, new protocol. Repair hull breach.
Do I take it to mean this ship's sinking?
Afraid so, unless the Cybermen get a shift on.
Blithering idiot! What about our loot?
You won't be seeing that again, Borthwick. Do exactly as I tell you and I'll try to see you escape with your lives.
Oh no, Doctor. It's every man for himself. You fellows, to the lifeboats. Follow me.
Squeaking of falls lowering lifeboat from davit.
That's it. Lift the lifeboat from the cradle. Not so fast. Steady, steady.
All of you stop. Stop now. Stop! Because I've seen the future and none of you, none of you will live if you jump ship like this. Stay and I'll do my best to find a way to save you.
Gentlemen, we'll have to jump for it. It's only twenty feet or so. Ready? Three, two, one. Geronimo!
Come on in, the water's lovely.
How can you be so sure, Doctor? It can't be so very far to land.
They won't make it, Madeleine. There's only one person escapes that way. You.
The Web of Time says different. Trust me.
Bon voyage, Doctor. You fellows, it's in and out, in, out.
This isn't the boat race, Borthwick. Come back before it's too late.
The men start singing Botany Bay'.
They're not good men, Doctor, if it makes any difference.
Good or bad, the Web of Time doesn't care. Now for Charley. Come on, the bridge.
A mine, I expect. I warned them.
Door slides closed. Radio frequency adjusted.
What are you looking for, the World Service?
Oh, a bit further. That's what they used to take over Byron, wasn't it?
Byron? Oh, you mean his grandfather. Yes, I expect. What happened to him, by the way?
Well, his brain sort of collapsed.
Cybercontrol signal causes deterioration of unaugmented brain, that's what they said. Come on, shouldn't you be getting on with whatever it is you're doing? CYBER-CHARLEY: Cybermen, seize them.
I'm walking away. I'm walking away, all right?

CYBER-CHARLEY: You thought you could save Charlotte Pollard by overwriting the CyberPlanner protocols imprinted on her brain. But her brain will be dead within the hour. Her synapses wither as I speak.
But then you will die too, CyberPlanner.
CYBER-CHARLEY: Fact. Human brain incapable of sustaining Cyber consciousness. Fact. Time Lord brain capable of sustaining Cyber consciousness.
CYBER-CHARLEY: Kill the girl. She has no value.
Doctor, you said I'd be saved!
You were there in the future. You can't die now.
CYBER-CHARLEY: Is that what he told you?
He said the Web of Time would protect me.
CYBER-CHARLEY: He lied. Charlotte Pollard fell through the Web of Time. Charlotte Pollard died and still lived. The future can always be changed. Destroy her.
The Cybermen and the radio squeal.
(through radio) CyberPlanner, prepare to receive new transmission. Your name is Charlotte Pollard. Are you receiving me? Your name is Charlotte Pollard.
My name is Charlotte Pollard. My name is Charlotte Pollard.
(through radio) Oh dear. CyberPlanner, your Cybermen seem a bit confused. Hadn't you better do something about that?
CYBER-CHARLEY: All Cybermen listen to me. Retreat to beyond range of control transmissions.
(through radio) The hold would be good. It's lead lined.
CYBER-CHARLEY: Retreat to the hold and await further instructions.
(through radio) How about this order cannot be countermanded, just to be on the safe side.
CYBER-CHARLEY: (struggling) This order cannot, cannot be countermanded. No! CyberPlanner will not be manipulated. I am the CyberPlanner. I am. I. I.
(through radio) Your name is Charlotte Pollard. Repeat. Your name is Charlotte Pollard.
Yes. Madeleine, help me with her. Madeleine?
(slowly) There is no Madeleine here. My name is Charlotte Pollard.
2: Wait. The CyberPlanner is not accounted for.
CyberPlanner's instructions cannot be countermanded. Seal the hold and await further instructions.
And there they will remain until that fool Byron wakes them up in 2008. Translated between 1942 and 500,002 every time there's a storm.
My name is Charlotte Pollard. This order cannot be countermanded. Charlotte Pollard.
You sure she's going to be all right?
Web of Time says so. A single survivor picked up from a lonely lifeboat. Cold, wet and amnesiac. I wonder.
If that's the way to save your life.
The control signal burnt out Byron's brain. Madeleine, she just got a touch of it and it destroyed her memory.

It's a neural worm. It uses the memory to exert its influence over the brain. Now, if you were a Time Lord you'd just pop yourself into a coma for a bit while your brain got on with cauterising the affected sections itself.
And that'd be all right, would it?
You might lose a few hours worth of memory, not much. But you're not a Time Lord, are yOu.
So we need a blunt instrument.
I taught Freud the technique. It won't hurt, but I need to make you forget, before it's too late.
Everything. Charley, if we don't starve the control worm soon, you
I'm afraid so. Look at the watch, Charley.
I don't want to, Doctor. I don't want to forget about you.
You must. Anything that might prompt you to remember today might allow the control worm to survive. Forget.
Like I can just do that. Venice, Orson Welles, C'Rizz.
Look at the watch, Charley. Forget.
(tired) It won't work. Not on me. It won't.
Back and forth. To and fro. (sotto) Forget. (echoes)
Oh no, but that's where I'm going. Come on, we've got to turn it around.
Don't worry, there's an easier way back.
I've got a box, bigger on the inside than the out.
How can something be bigger on the inside than on the (trails off) outside? Oh.
No, no, no, no, no. How.
(memory) There, you've got the hang of it already.
You've got the hang of it already.
(memory) Remarkable mind, Lenin. Terrible at tiddlywinks.
You. You're the Doctor. You might just be the oddest man I've ever met.
Oh, don't start that again. Don't you see? Some things are too good to be forgotten. Tell you what, shall we explore?
So, where to now, Miss Pollard?
Too noisy. The sacking of Londinium.
Too much Boudica. I know, the Jovian Fold.
That's the one. Sumaran dateline 925 point 35. Oh, you'll love it, Charley, You're going to love it. The Millennium Mardi Gras, the party to end all parties.
Just don't do anything rash, Doctor.
Or I'll rip her head off her shoulders. Capisci?
Byron's voice has a slight reverberation.
It's Super-Byron now. Man, you've no idea how fantastic this feels.
(strangled) And you've no idea how restricting this feels.
Sorry, not used to my own strength yet. Better?
Byron, it was too late to go back for you.
Ah, you didn't even try. Fact is, when you sunk the Batavia, they'd hardly started my conversion, so when I saw the Tardis door open I thought hell, why not?
Only stopping for a spot of matricide.
Hey, do you know what that old trout did to my old man?
Figured I'd be best off sitting here and waiting my chance. After all, if you didn't get things right in the past, I might never get born. Correct?
You don't want to mess with the Web of Time, Byron.
The Batavia's out of bounds, if that's what you're thinking. We're not going back there, past, present or future.
Just as well, cos that's not where we're going. Got another salvage operation in mind, as it happens.
Oh, you think? I'm thinking, damaged or no, that Cybership is gonna be packed full of technology. That's where the future is, Doctor. Right.
's all right. I don't need a hostage.
Cos the Doctor's going to do exactly what I want once he's been zapped by this.
Byron, the CyberPlanner can't help you. It's knackered, demented, kaput.
Oh yeah? I've got these jacks in my head now, and when I plug them in like so
Electronic sound, the Doctor cries out in pain.
I can control your every deed. Good, isn't it?
Forget it. He won't answer to you. Doctor. Doctor.
Take us to the year 500,002, there's a good fella.
Useful to have around, ain't he?
You can't just switch him on and off.
Course I can. I can make him dance and jump and sing, anything.
Oh, and that amuses you, does it?
Actually, it doesn't. Must be something to do with the new Cyberbrain. And seeing as now I've got a pretty good idea how to control your Tardis, I won't be needing him at all, will I
Hurt him? Course not. No more than I'd hurt the toaster when I pull the plug.
Charley. Don't forget what I told
There's no heartbeat. Nor here. You killed him!
Not to Cybermen, right? Me and you, we're brothers.
This human has been cybernetically enhanced. Conversion is incomplete. Abort him.
No, wait! He's got your CyberPlanner.
What the hell do you think you're playing at?
(Cyber voice) No. I have been asked to return the CyberPlanner to its er
CyberPlanner must be reinstalled in control centre.
(Cyber voice) Yes. You will escort us there.
(Cyber voice) Left, right, left, right. Halt.
2: Wait. Confirm CyberPlanner not corrupted first.
2: CyberPlanner last reported in area infected by temporal corrosion. Temporal corrosion might cause total systems collapse. Protocol demands CyberPlanner must be placed in quarantine.
Oh, that'll take too long. Byron!
So he does. It is an uneven fight.
Okay, install CyberPlanner. This bit must go in here, and this bit goes in here. Oh no. No, no, no, no, no. Must be in here. Ah ha!
Update. CyberPlanner reinstalled in Cybership mainframe. Systems check.
You boys can't even scratch me.
Byron, they've taken your arm off.
You've got a touch of rust, CyberPlanner.
No. No. Uninstall me. I must not infect the ship.
Nasty. Oh man, it's on me now. Oh, it hurts. Charley! Charley, please!
Goodbye, Byron. I can't say it's been pleasant.
Please, you've got to help me! Please!
I don't know why you're chasing me, you won't get much sustenance.
Autodestruction of Cybership predicted in sixty microspans. Fifty nine.
Oh, put a sock in it, CyberPlanner.
It's not chasing me, it's after. Oh no, the Tardis.
Yes, yes, I can make it.
No! The HADS! No, not again!
Oh. After all, what could possibly go wrong.
Update. Prognosis revised. Total systems collapse predicted.
The Tardis materialises and the door opens.
Now, where was I? Singapore, Singapore Harbour. Charley, one minute!
(on telephone) No, we have no doubles available. Singles, yes. Oh, snuggle up? Certainly, sir, but that will be at the double rate.
Charley? Charley? Where's she gone now?
I do apologise. Are you a guest, sir?
Oh! Yes, of course. I'll just fetch your key.
No, no, I don't want. Your clocks are wrong.
I shouldn't think so, sir. They're beryllium chipped.
It has been a long night, hasn't it? Your key and your bill, dated back to 1926.
Bill. Oh, yes. Oh, my head is swimming.
I'm sure it is, sir. (tannoy) Security to Reception. Thank you.
I've er cards in here somewhere. Oh. Gold ingot do you?
That'll do nicely, sir. (tannoy) Security, as you were.
Do you know, I've absolutely no idea how that got in there. Anyway, I meant to ask, have you seen a girl, about so high.
Oh, of course. There was a girl left you a message round about midnight.
[OC]: Dear Doctor. Its been such a long journey for both of us. I never, ever wanted it to end, but end it has. We both know that.

[OC]: A long time ago now, I said you were the oddest man I'd ever met. You're that still. You're the best man Ive ever met too. But weve chanced our luck once too often, I think, so Im bailing out. Escape strategy number five.

[OC]: Im going to disappear. Theres no freedom like being dead. I can go anywhere, be anyone I want. Just like a Time Lord really. Dont look for me, please. But remember me. I'll remember you, always. With love, The Girl Who Never Was.
Sir? Are you all right, Doctor?
You work in a hotel. You should know. Everybody leaves.

Memoirs of an Edwardian Adventuress, continued. When I was a little girl, we stayed a season at Ostend, the Cannes of the North. I'd been reading Treasure Island and I got it into my head to send messages in bottles off the pier, all with my name and address inside. Hundreds of them, sent drifting off to who knows where. Spitzbergen, Zanzibar, New Zealand, other places with the letter Z. I never got anything back. Hundreds of bottles, nothing back. What are the chances of that? So here I am, on my own desert island, washed up when the Cybership broke up, a castaway at last. But I'm sending out my messages still. Never say die. Hmm. He's be so proud of me, the Doctor. I've managed to build a crystal set from the debris, and every hour, on the hour, I tap it out. Dot dot dot, dash dash dash, dot dot dot, over and over and over. Someone's listening, somewhere. Dot dot dot, dash dash dash, dot dot dot. (gasps)
Oh! Oh! He's alive! Oh, he's alive!
[OC]: (crying) Oh God, thank you. Open up! Open up!
I knew it. I knew you'd come back.
Oh, I'm sorry. I was expecting someone else.
